title: Getting started as a DJ: Mixing, mashups and digital turntables - Cole Plante

multiple-choice.question: What is a primary objective of a DJ during a performance?

options.text: To showcase their skills on a single instrument.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.text: The lyrics.

options.label: D

options.text: To create a new song from scratch.

options.label: B
options.text: To mix tracks and create a seamless musical journey.

options.label: C
options.text: To adjust the volume levels of individual tracks.

options.label: D
options.text: To add effects to the music, such as beat rolls and filters.

options.label: A
options.text: Investing in expensive equipment.

options.label: B
options.text: Asking a friend who knows how to DJ.

options.label: C
options.text: Using online resources and tutorials.

options.label: D
options.text: Starting with a low-cost app or software.

options.label: A
options.text: Watching podcasts and live sets.

options.label: B
options.text: Asking a friend who knows how to DJ.

options.label: C
options.text: Checking out YouTube and online resources.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: CDJs.

options.label: B
options.text: Ableton.

options.label: C
options.text: Traktor Pro.

multiple-choice.question: What is a significant advantage of modern technology in DJing, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: That only a few people can afford the equipment.

options.label: B
options.text: That only a few people can learn how to DJ.

options.label: C
options.text: That only a few people can create new music.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in the amount of information being shared online.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in the amount of information being shared online.

options.label: C
options.text: A shift from human editors to algorithmic filters controlling the flow of information.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Facebook removed them because they were deemed irrelevant.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are too slow at recommending content, leading to frustration.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive to implement and maintain.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by saying that we may have the story about the internet wrong?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The internet is not as useful as we thought it was.

options.label: C
options.text: The internet is not as democratic as we thought it was, with algorithms controlling the flow of information.

options.label: D
options.text: The internet is not as good as we thought it was.

options.label: A
options.text: The responsibility to prioritize relevance over importance.

options.label: B
options.text: The responsibility to prioritize entertainment over information.

options.label: C
options.text: The responsibility to prioritize civic responsibility and promote diversity of opinion.

options.label: D
options.text: The responsibility to prioritize profit over people.

options.label: B
options.text: We need the internet to be better and more efficient.

options.label: C
options.text: We need the internet to connect us all together and promote diversity of opinion.

options.text: We need the internet to be more entertaining and engaging.

options.label: B
options.text: We need to make the internet more democratic and promote diversity of opinion.

options.label: C
options.text: We need to make the internet more responsible and prioritize civic responsibility.

options.label: D

options.text: The presence of dark matter

multiple-choice.question: What is dark matter, and how does it interact with normal matter?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of galaxy that interacts with normal matter

options.label: B
options.text: A type of star that interacts with normal matter

options.label: C
options.text: A type of particle that interacts with normal matter through all fundamental forces

options.label: D
options.text: A type of particle that interacts with normal matter primarily through gravity

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is one way to study dark matter?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing its effects on galaxy clusters

options.label: B
options.text: By detecting its presence in the lab

options.label: C
options.text: By modeling its behavior on computers

options.label: D
options.text: By studying its effects on the universe at large scales

multiple-choice.question: What is dark energy, and what is its role in the universe?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of matter that makes up the universe

options.label: B
options.text: A type of energy that drives the expansion of the universe at an ever-increasing rate

options.label: C
options.text: A type of radiation that comes from galaxies

options.label: D
options.text: A type of particle that doesn't interact with normal matter

multiple-choice.question: According to Henry Ford, what would people have said if asked what they wanted in terms of transportation?

options.label: A
options.text: Faster cars

options.label: B
options.text: More efficient cars

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why do we cry? The three types of tears - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about Iris's lacrimal glands?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce tears only in response to emotional stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: They produce a limited amount of tears per day.

options.label: C
options.text: They produce a constant flow of tears to keep her eyes moist, with a significant daily output of thirty gallons per year.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only active when Iris is sad.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the basal tears that Iris constantly produces?

options.label: A
options.text: To wash away harmful substances or particles.

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize Iris's mood as quickly as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: To keep dirt and debris away from her eyes and maintain eye health by forming a thin coating of three layers.

options.label: D
options.text: To elicit sympathy or show submission.

multiple-choice.question: What triggers Iris's uncontrollable crying when Onion takes off her jacket?

options.label: A
options.text: The smell of Onion's perfume.

options.label: B
options.text: The sight of Onion's jacket.

options.label: C
options.text: The chemical reaction that converts sulfoxides into sulfenic acid, releasing a gas that irritates Iris's eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: Iris's emotional state.

multiple-choice.question: How do reflex tears differ from basal tears?

options.label: A
options.text: Reflex tears are released in smaller amounts, while basal tears are released in larger amounts.

options.label: B
options.text: Reflex tears are released in larger amounts, while basal tears are released in smaller amounts, to wash away harmful substances.

options.label: C
options.text: Reflex tears contain fewer antibodies, while basal tears contain more antibodies.

options.label: D
options.text: Reflex tears have the same chemical composition as basal tears.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the primary functions of emotional tears?

options.label: A
options.text: To wash away harmful substances or particles.

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize Iris's mood as quickly as possible and provide emotional relief.

options.label: C
options.text: To elicit sympathy or show submission.

options.label: D
options.text: To signal Iris's emotional state to others.

multiple-choice.question: According to the story, what is one possible function of emotional tears?

options.label: A
options.text: To calm Iris down and signal her emotional state to others.

options.label: B
options.text: To increase Iris's heart rate and breathing rate.

options.label: C
options.text: To wash away harmful substances or particles.

options.label: D
options.text: To elicit sympathy or show submission.

multiple-choice.question: How do emotional tears differ from reflex tears?

options.label: A
options.text: Emotional tears are released in response to physical stimuli, while reflex tears are released in response to emotional stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: Emotional tears are released in larger amounts, while reflex tears are released in smaller amounts.

options.label: C
options.text: Emotional tears contain more stress hormones, while reflex tears contain more antibodies to fight off infections.

options.label: D
options.text: Emotional tears have the same chemical composition as reflex tears.

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of the relationship between Iris and Onion?

options.label: A
options.text: They are best friends.

options.label: B
options.text: They are romantic partners who have a strong emotional connection.

options.label: C
options.text: They are acquaintances.

options.label: D
options.text: They are siblings.

multiple-choice.question: Why do Iris and Onion decide to end their relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Iris is too sensitive.

options.label: B
options.text: Because Onion's smell is a problem.

options.label: C
options.text: Because Iris hurts and cries every time Onion takes off her jacket, causing them distress.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have different interests.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall message of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: That Iris's sensitivity is a weakness.

options.label: B
options.text: That Onion's smell is a problem.

options.label: C
options.text: That Iris's tears are a social mechanism to elicit sympathy or show submission.

options.label: D
options.text: That as long as Iris has all three kinds of tears working to keep her balanced and healthy, she will be able to cope with challenges and move forward.
